pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 45387  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Strengthening Capacity of Developing Member 
Countries in Resource Mobilization and 
 
Implementation of Cofinanced Projects

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  -  Asian Development Bank  
  DMC  -  developing member country 
  TA  -  technical assistance  
TASF  -  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
    
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
     
Type                                    -  Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  -  General intervention  
Sector   -  Multisector  
Theme   -  Capacity development (client relations, network and partnership 
development) 
Location impact  -  Regional (medium) 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Head  C. L.H.F. Gregory, Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) 
   
Team leader  T. Dojima, Principal Financing Partnerships Specialist, OCO  
Team member  M. Soriano, Senior Operations and Institutional Coordination Officer, 
OCO 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development 
Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area

1 
 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  One of the goals of Strategy 2020—the long-term strategic framework of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB)—is increased partnership-based cofinancing and implementing of 
ADB operations.1 The strategy specifies that ADB’s cofinancing will increase at a faster rate 
than its stand-alone financing operations, with a long-term objective of having total annual direct 
cofinancing  exceed  the  value  of  ADB’s  standalone  project  financing.  Specifically,  ADB’s 
cofinancing partnerships aim to (i) mobilize additional financial resources through cofinancing; 
(ii) complement and draw upon the comparative advantage and knowledge of its partners; and 
(iii)  broaden,  replicate,  and  sustain  its  development  impact  by  ensuring  coordination  and 
avoiding duplication. This regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) project will 
benefit developing member countries (DMCs) by enhancing timely cofinancing opportunities and 
deepening dialogue between potential donors and recipient DMC governments at the pre-
project design stage. It will also add to DMCs’ knowledge about each donor’s development 
agenda and unique policies, guidelines, and requirements for financing partnerships. 
 
2.  To be successful in official cofinanced projects, DMC governments need to be familiar 
with (i) their current and potential donors’ priority areas of financing, (ii) cofinancing procedures 
and regulations, and (iii) ADB’s cofinancing frameworks. The TA will provide a range of tools to 
support DMCs with donors to gain this knowledge. It will also enhance the networks of DMCs, 
donors,  and  ADB,  including  the  Resident  Mission  and  Representative  Offices  Cofinancing 
Anchors Network established in early 2011.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The ability of DMC governments to strategize their approach to donors’ aid frameworks 
varies across regions, countries, and agencies. A lack of knowledge about donors’ requirements 
and procedures may limit DMCs’ access to potential new financing opportunities and result in 
weak  policy  dialogue  and  results  monitoring,  and  less  attractive  sector  and  thematic 
development scenarios. There are a number of common challenges, including insufficient staff 
resources combined with high staff turnover and weak knowledge transfer. 
 
4.  In order for DMCs to respond to recent challenges, it is important to have a sophisticated 
results-monitoring  environment.  Because  of  donors’  growing  demands  for  more  stringent 
management practices of cofinanced projects and reporting of development results, as well as a 
more  focused  and  streamlined  approach  to  strategic  development,  precise  knowledge  of  
donors’ detailed requirements is crucial. 
 
5.  The  need  to  develop  a  wider  range  of  cofinancing  opportunities  is  driven  by  (i) 
challenges in the global partner environment, (ii) the emergence and availability of efficient 
information sharing mechanisms, and (iii) a more sophisticated framework of match making 
between the needs of DMCs and potential donors. This requires a variety of tailor-made tools, 
including information technology solutions, so that ADB can be more effective and efficient in 
addressing the demands of both potential donors and recipient governments. The TA framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

2 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The TA will contribute to DMCs by assisting them to increase their portfolio of cofinanced 
projects in line with ADB’s long-term objective of increasing direct value-added cofinancing. This 
will be measured by the Strategy 2020 monitoring reports for the progress of partnerships. The 
TA project outcome will be a more systematic approach to potential donors for increasing 
cofinancing opportunities for DMCs. The impact of this TA will be measured by the increased 
pipeline  of  potential  cofinancing  projects,  more  practical  dialogue  on  the  potential  future 
financing  opportunities  and  collaboration  with  ADB,  and  closer  person-to-person  networks 
among DMC officials, the cofinancing anchors network, and donors. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The outcome will be achieved through three outputs. The first output will be to develop 
comprehensive tools and materials for the external financing opportunity seminars, which will be 
carried out for selected DMCs. Representatives from the donors’ field offices will also be invited. 
This component will include research on donors to identify their official aid budget framework, 
including the authority and responsibilities delegated to their field offices. The results of this 
research will be one of the key inputs of the Financial Partners Handbook to be produced under 
the second output of the TA. The seminar materials will also include (i) general requirements 
and procedures for processing projects with cofinancing, (ii) the cofinancing opportunities that 
exist  at  each  stage  of  the  project  cycle,  and  (iii)  ADB’s  procedures  for  implementing  and 
administering projects with cofinancing. Several case studies will be included, particularly on 
projects with issues. The seminar will be conducted in at least three DMCs. Lessons learned, 
including participant feedback, will be shared with other DMCs to improve successive seminars.  
 
8.  The second output will be a Financial Partners Handbook based mainly on the research 
conducted for the first output. This handbook will include each donor’s (i) governance structure 
for official development assistance budget decision making; (ii) process for setting their aid 
target areas; (iii) current potential or notional amounts for each aid target; (iv) procedures on 
how to allocate the aid budget for each field office; (v) relationship between their capital’s central 
aid budget unit and field offices, and the background for their delegation of power and authority; 
and (vi) critical issues relating to each donor for DMCs’ awareness. For this component, the TA 
implementation  team  will  pay  careful  attention  to  honoring  each  donor’s  confidentiality 
requirements. 
 
9.  To maintain the sustainability and improve the quality of information for stakeholders, it 
is essential to have a strong platform for a knowledge network. The third output of this TA will be 
the establishment of such a platform to provide practical benefits to the network participants. 
Supported by the cofinancing anchors network, the TA implementation team will identify and 
survey the potential beneficiaries of the network to identify their needs and anticipated benefits. 
After developing a framework and an organizational modality, the team will examine with the 
beneficiaries the feasibility of the network’s sustainability. This component will also include 
developing an appropriate database for single and multi-donor trust funds, including Financing 
Partnership Facilities. Finally, the TA will announce the establishment of the network to the 
relevant agencies to ensure its visibility.

3 
 
10.  The  selection  of  DMCs2  will  be  based  on  consultations  with  regional  departments 
considering the following criteria: (i) the number of cofinancing transactions: current portfolio 
and pipelines; (ii) the type, frequency, and complexity of cofinancing arrangements, issues, or 
problems; (iii) the number and operations of cofinancing partners present in the DMC; (iv) the 
openness of the DMC to cofinancing; and (v) the willingness of the resident mission to host the 
seminar. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-other sources). The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB is the executing agency. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance 
with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (April 2010, as amended from time to time). The assignment will require input from 
international (10 person-months) and national (18 person-months) consultants on an intermittent 
basis. The consultants will be recruited on an individual basis.  
 
13.  The Office of Cofinancing Operations will lead the implementation of the TA and will 
cooperate with the cofinancing anchors network. The TA will be implemented over 18 months 
(from 1 February 2012 to 31 July 2013). The TA implementation team—in collaboration with 
members of the cofinancing anchors network—will submit work plans, organize cofinancing 
opportunity seminars, coordinate and participate in the events, and collate statistics and data to 
measure the TA performance. Consultants will assist TA implementation by (i) handling the 
logistical aspects, (ii) carrying out the activities in paras. 7–9, and (iii) suggesting a possible 
future plan and improvements in conducting the seminars and maintaining the network. The 
outline terms of reference for these consultancy services are in Appendix 3.  
 
14.  For cofinancing opportunity seminars, resident missions will be responsible for all local 
arrangements such as issuing invitations to interested participants and providing conference 
rooms, audiovisual equipment, and secretarial assistance. The host organizers,3 if any, may 
provide financial assistance for the participants, including the costs of renting conference rooms 
and lunch. ADB will provide the resource speakers and seminar materials.  
 
15.  Should the donors request cofinancing opportunities seminars, the Office of Cofinancing 
Operations will communicate with the host organization and design and plan the seminar in 
close cooperation with the organizers to suit their particular needs and preferences. Seminars 
will be conducted in English. The Office of Cofinancing Operations recommends the seminars 
last 1 day each.  
 
16.  In case there are any additional events proposed and sponsored by any donor and/or 
DMC, these will be carefully assessed on a case-by-case basis, using agreed criteria to ensure 
that  the  events  are  complementary  and  the  links  with  the  seminar  add  value.  Criteria  for 
                                                 
2 Special consideration may need to be given to Group A countries with less cofinancing experience, if regional 
departments require. 
3 Like the Business Opportunities Seminar, any donor agency or development partner organization can offer to host.

4 
 
identifying suitable additional events may include the following: (i) the events are well publicized, 
(ii) the theme is consistent with cofinancing opportunities offered by the donors and ADB, (iii) 
the participants’ profile fits the target group for ADB cofinancing opportunities, (iv) there are 
opportunities for meaningful interaction among network participants, and (v) the organizers have 
experience delivering well-organized events. 
 
17.  For the Financial Partners Handbook, the international consultant will be required during 
the inception of the TA to identify donors whose detailed information are not available in public 
documents; the consultant may then recommend visiting the headquarters of those donors. With 
consent from each such donor’s headquarters, ADB may send the consultant to those countries 
within the TA budget. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening  Capacity  of  Developing  Member  Countries  in  Resource  Mobilization  and 
Implementation of Cofinanced Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

5

8 
Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work  
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) will require the services of 
one international consultant and two national consultants. 
 
2.  The international consultant should have extensive experience in and knowledge of (i) 
donor countries’ external assistance budget process and framework, and budget allocation 
mechanism including governance structure; and (ii) relationships between their capitals and field 
offices, embassies, and aid agencies. He or she should have direct access to some of the donor 
countries’ key personnel for aid budget decision-making processes and/or experience working 
with  them.  Also,  he  or  she  should  have  knowledge  of  a  donor  relationship  management 
framework  of  at  least  one  of  the  multilateral  development  banks4  including  their  internal 
procedures for obtaining donors’ funds for their projects either though establishing trust funds or 
project specific cofinancing. 
 
3.  One of the national consultants should have (i) experience organizing and preparing 
seminars financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under TA projects, (ii) sufficient 
knowledge of ADB’s project operations and cofinancing operations, (iii) and experience or 
knowledge developing and/or coordinating knowledge networks for ADB activities. 
 
4.  The other national consultant should have experience designing and creating databases 
for monitoring financial products (e.g., loans, investments, and contingent liabilities) and for 
financial portfolio management and analysis. The consultant needs to demonstrate familiarity 
with the IBM e-Business Suite and/or similar platforms and Web 2.0 collaboration systems. He 
or she should have at least 5 years’ work experience in a web development role. Sufficient 
knowledge of business procedures and requirements of ADB’s Office of Information Systems 
and Technology will be an advantage. Excellent skills for Microsoft Excel and Access are also 
required. 
 
5.  All consultants will report to the director and principal financing partnerships specialist of 
the Office of Cofinancing Operations (supervisors) as a team led by the international consultant.   
 
B.  International Consultant 
 
  1.  Fund Mobilization Specialist (10 months) 
 
6.  The fund mobilization specialist will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  as team leader, manage the national business administration expert and the 
database development expert; 
(ii)  conduct  interviews  with  representatives  of  concerned  donor  countries  in 
coordination with members of the ADB Board of Directors, as necessary and 
allowed,  to  find  out  the  broader  structure  of  their  governments’  aid  budget 
framework, procedures, and governance structure; 
(iii)  in  case  such  information  is  not  available  through  interviews,  consult  key 
personnel of each government to obtain the information; 
                                                 
4  Knowledge of the past works of the Office of Outreach and Partnerships of Inter American Development Bank for 
their Donor Handbook would be an advantage.

9 
Appendix 3 
(iv)  carry out an in-depth study of each government’s governance structure for official 
development assistance budget decision making; the process for setting their aid 
target  areas;  current,  potential,  or  notional  amounts  for  each  aid  target, 
procedures on how to allocate the aid budget for field offices, and the relationship 
of their capitals’ central units for aid budget with field offices (the consultant will 
be required to suggest detailed study items before proceeding with the study); 
(v)  draft  the  Financial  Partners  Handbook,  which  contains  comprehensive 
information of each donor’s aid budget framework as one of the materials for 
cofinancing opportunities seminars (the soft copy should be available for future 
updates); 
(vi)  manage the publication of the handbook, excluding the information that any 
donor has a  restriction to disclose; 
(vii)  conduct a similar survey  relying on resident mission anchors network members 
for donors’ field offices; 
(viii)  in  coordination  with  resident  missions,  where  there  is  an  established  donor 
coordination  framework  such  as  the  local  consultative  group  in  Bangladesh, 
reflect good practices in the seminar materials; 
(ix)  develop efficient and effective seminar design and delivery mechanisms focusing 
on donors’ specific needs, priorities in selected developing member countries 
(DMCs)  including  recommendations  for  DMC  participants,  general  conditions 
from  ADB’s  side  for  the  donors  related  to  the  cofinancing  operation,  and 
implementation issues based on the experiences of the regional departments 
and resident missions;  
(x)  develop seminar materials, standardized agendas, and proceedings; 
(xi)  conduct pilot seminars for selected DMCs; 
(xii)  modify and make necessary adjustments to seminar materials based on pilot 
seminars, including participant surveys;  
(xiii)  suggest  modifications  to  the  detailed  design  of  Phase  2  and  onwards,  if 
appropriate; and 
(xiv)  provide comprehensive reports covering all outputs including the detailed design 
of the next stages, such as Phase 2 and onwards. 
 
C.  National consultants 
 
  1.  Business Administration Expert for Fund Mobilization (12 months) 
 
7.  The business administration expert will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  assist the team leader with all tasks; 
(ii)  perform  secretariat    support  for  TA  administration,  including  assisting  with 
coordinating seminars, managing facilities, processing payments, and developing 
document templates; 
(iii)  arrange logistics for conferences, workshops, and meetings; organize venues; 
make travel arrangements for participants; and arrange transfers of funds and 
payments; and 
(iv)  assist  resident  mission  anchors  and  resource  persons  in  the  Office  of 
Cofinancing Operations  with tasks related to cofinancing opportunities seminars. 
 
   2.  Business Database Development Expert (6 months) 
 
8.  The business database development expert will carry out the following tasks:

10 
Appendix 3 
 
(i)  review  the  current  database  relating  to  trust  funds  and  project  specific 
cofinancing used in the Office of Cofinancing Operations and identify weakness 
in its management and operational frameworks;  
(ii)  recommend improvements, modify the programs as necessary, and develop a 
comprehensive database of ADB’s cofinancing opportunity knowledge sharing for 
the new network platform; 
(iii)  lead discussions and negotiations with the Office of Information Systems and 
Technology for implementing these improvements and developing new database 
as required; and 
(iv)  develop two operational manuals for the database: a short (10 pages or less) and  
simple reference for those that are not familiar with information technology (the 
majority  of  the  network  participants)  and  another  reference  for  information 
technology experts for possible future modifications of the database. 
 
D.  Report requirements 
 
9.  The consultants will provide material according to the following schedule:  
(i)  an inception report including detailed work schedules, 5–10 pages and 1 page 
schedule table in calendar type (2 weeks after the team leader’s engagement);  
(ii)  the design and outline of the Financial Partners Handbook (2 months after the 
team leader’s engagement);.  
(iii)  the  first  draft  outline  of  the  handbook  (3  months  after  the  team  leader’s 
engagement);  
(iv)  the second draft outline of the handbook (4 months after the team leader’s 
engagement);  
(v)  the final draft of the handbook, the first draft of the cofinancing opportunities 
seminar materials, and draft manuals for the database (6 months after the team 
leader’s engagement);  
(vi)  the final materials for the cofinancing opportunities seminar (8 months after the 
team leader’s engagement);  
(vii)  the final draft report, 10–15 pages (3 weeks prior to the end of the engagement); 
and  
(viii)  the final report, 10–15 pages plus appendixes or as necessary, and the required 
manuals for the database (the end of the engagement)..
